qas.question: What parts of reptiles respond to sensory cues?
What is the principal sense of night-active mammals?
Why were early mammals active at night?
What developed from the mammalian odor pathways?
How do the olfactory lobes of mammals compare in size to those of reptiles?
What parts of reptiles don't respond to sensory cues?
What is the principal sense of morning-active mammals?
Why were early mammals active in the morning?
What developed from the mammalian sonic pathways?
How do the olfactory lobes of mammals not compare in size to those of reptiles?

context: The <a0_0><b5_0>motor centers<b5_0/><a0_0/> of reptiles react to sensory cues of vision, sound, touch, chemical, gravity, and motion with pre-set body movements and programmed postures. With the arrival of night-active mammals, <a1_0><b6_0>smell<b6_0/><a1_0/> replaced vision as the dominant sense, and a different way of responding arose from the olfactory sense, which is proposed to have developed into mammalian emotion and emotional memory. The mammalian brain invested heavily in olfaction to succeed at night as <a2_0><b7_0>reptiles slept<b7_0/><a2_0/>—one explanation for why olfactory lobes in mammalian brains are proportionally <a4_0><b9_0>larger<b9_0/><a4_0/> than in the reptiles. These odor pathways gradually formed the neural blueprint for what was later to become our <a3_0><b8_0>limbic brain<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
